Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A Generalized Framework for Securing Heterogeneous Multicore Architectures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project envisions a mixed-security system where some components are trusted while others are not-trusted. This includes both hardware and software. The target hardware platform is a heterogeneous multicore system-on-a-chip where some hardware cores are trusted and other cores are untrusted. The applications executing on this multicore substrate are similarly made out of tasks where some tasks require secure execution and other tasks may be unsecured. The problem is highly relevant to so-called "Internet of Things" systems built from trusted and untrusted components.

This proposal conceptualizes a mixed security computing framework that implements user-defined security policies executing on a heterogeneous mixed-trust multicore system-on-a-chip. Four hardware trust "zones" are considered, ranging from highly trusted, somewhat trusted, untrusted to unknown; tasks belonging to an application may execute accordingly based on its security requirement. The project will investigate software-defined security policies and develop hardware hooks to support the software defined security goals. Among other broader impacts, the PI is developing new teaching materials and will pilot a hardware-software co-design course on Hardware-Oriented Cyber Security. This project will also help in that educational effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cyber security is now a critical concern in a wide range of embedded computing modules, communications systems, and connected devices used in medical electronics, automotive systems, power grid systems, military equipment, robotics and public safety and avionics. In current systems-on-chip (SoCs) designs, processing elements, i.e., intellectual property (IP) cores, may come from different providers and executable code may have varying levels of trust. This design approach creates a very fertile attack ground in heterogeneous SoC architectures and distributed connected devices. 

The objectives of the project were (1) to define an architectural template for user to specify system runtime security policies as opposed to static design or manufacturing time security specifications, (2) to devise software and hardware supports for integrating mixed-security system where some components are trusted while others are not-trusted, and (3) to formulate a set of dynamic authentication and enforcement of security policies rooted in the hardware. 

The outcome of the project is a mixed security computing framework that implements user-defined security policies executing on a heterogeneous, mixed-trust multicore system-on-a-chip. The project has advanced the computer design community’s ability to architect secure heterogeneous computing systems through the development of a generalized, user-defined security-policies framework for integrating IP processing elements from different sources and trust levels. 

The project produced (i) a protocol for reconstructing secrets and information in distributed computing systems even in the presence of a large number of untrusted components, (ii) a Multi-Identity Physical Unclonable Function (Mi-PUF) assisted, weighted, group decision making scheme to support context-aware authentication, and (iii) an adaptive and dynamic device authentication technique using chaotic systems as lightweight one-way functions. Additionally, the project provided student training opportunities and course materials.
